column2: I remain forever your brother in Christ,
column3: I remain forever your brother in Christ,

column2: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND, 1859.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: JIM KELL, CHARLES HEATH, WILLIAM CARLISLE, CHARLES RINGGOLD, THOMAS MAXWELL, AND SAMUEL SMITH.
column3: JIM KELL, CHARLES HEATH, WILLIAM CARLISLE, CHARLES RINGGOLD, THOMAS MAXWELL, AND SAMUEL SMITH.

column2: On the evening of the Fourth of July, while all was hilarity and rejoicing the above named very interesting fugitives arrived from the troubled district, the Eastern shore, of Maryland, where so many conventions had been held the previous year to prevent escapes; where the Rev. Samuel Green had been convicted and sent to the penitentiary for ten years for having a copy of Uncle Tom's Cabin in his humble home; where so many parties, on escaping, had the good sense and courage to secure their flight by bringing their masters' horses and carriages a good way on their perilous journey.
column3: On the evening of the Fourth of July, while all was hilarity and rejoicing the above named very interesting fugitives arrived from the troubled district, the Eastern shore, of Maryland, where so many conventions had been held the previous year to prevent escapes; where the reverend Samuel Green had been convicted and sent to the penitentiary for ten years for having a copy of Uncle Tom's Cabin in his humble home; where so many parties, on escaping, had the good sense and courage to secure their flight by bringing their masters' horses and carriages a good way on their perilous journey.

column2: Sam had been tied up and beat many times severely.
column3: Sam had been tied up and beat many times severely.

column2: William had been stripped naked, and frequently and cruelly cowhided.
column3: William had been stripped naked, and frequently and cruelly cowhided.

column2: Thomas had been clubbed over his head more times than a few.
column3: Thomas had been clubbed over his head more times than a few.

column2: Jim had been whipped with clubs and switches times without number.
column3: Jim had been whipped with clubs and switches times without number.

column2: Charles had had five men on him at one time, with cowhides, his master in the lead.
column3: Charles had had five men on him at one time, with cowhides, his master in the lead.

column2: Charles Heath had had his head cut shockingly, with a club, in the hands of his master; this well cared-for individual in referring to his kind master, said: "I can give his character right along, he was a perfect devil.
column3: Charles Heath had had his head cut shockingly, with a club, in the hands of his master; this well cared for individual in referring to his kind master, said: "I can give his character right along, he was a perfect devil.

column2: The night we left, he had a woman tied up--God knows what he done.
column3: The night we left, he had a woman tied up-God knows what he done.

column2: He was always blustering, you could never do enough for him no how.
column3: He was always blustering, you could never do enough for him no how.

column2: First thing in the morning and last thing at night, you would hear him cussing--he would cuss in bed.
column3: First thing in the morning and last thing at night, you would hear him cussing-he would cuss in bed.

column2: He was a large farmer, all the time drunk.
column3: He was a large farmer, all the time drunk.

column2: He had a good deal of money but not much character.
column3: He had a good deal of money but not much character.

column2: He was a savage, bluff, red face-looking concern." Thus, in the most earnest, as well as in an intelligent manner, Charles described the man (Aquila Cain), who had hitherto held him under the yoke.
column3: He was a savage, bluff, red face looking concern." Thus, in the most earnest, as well as in an intelligent manner, Charles described the man (Aquila Cain), who had hitherto held him under the yoke.

column2: James left his mother, Nancy Kell, two brothers, Robert and Henry, and two sisters, Mary and Annie; all living in the neighborhood whence he fled.
column3: james left his mother, Nancy Kell, two brothers, Robert and Henry, and two sisters, Mary and Annie; all living in the neighborhood whence he fled.

column2: Besides these, he had eight brothers and sisters living in Baltimore and elsewhere, under the yoke.
column3: Besides these, he had eight brothers and sisters living in Baltimore and elsewhere, under the yoke.

column2: He was twenty-four years of age, of a jet color, but of a manly turn.
column3: He was twenty four years of age, of a jet color, but of a manly turn.

column2: He fled from Thomas Murphy, a farmer, and regular slave-holder.
column3: He fled from Thomas Murphy, a farmer, and regular slave holder.

column2: Charles Heath was twenty-five years of age, medium size, full black, a very keen-looking individual.
column3: Charles Heath was twenty five years of age, medium size, full black, a very keen looking individual.

column2: William was also of unmixed blood, shrewd and wide-awake for his years,--had been ground down under the heel of Aquila Cain.
column3: William was also of unmixed blood, shrewd and wide awake for his years,--had been ground down under the heel of Aquila Cain.

column2: He left his mother and two sisters.
column3: He left his mother and two sisters.

column2: Charles Ringgold was eighteen years of age; no white blood showed itself in the least in this individual.
column3: Charles Ringgold was eighteen years of age; no white blood showed itself in the least in this individual.

column2: He fled from Dr. Jacob Preston, a member of the Episcopal Church, and a practical farmer with twenty head of slaves.
column3: He fled from dr Jacob Preston, a member of the Episcopal Church, and a practical farmer with twenty head of slaves.

column2: He was not so bad, but his wife was said to be a 'stinger.' Charles left his mother and father behind, also four sisters.
column3: He was not so bad, but his wife was said to be a 'stinger.' Charles left his mother and father behind, also four sisters.

column2: Thomas was of pure blood, with a very cheerful, healthy-looking countenance,--twenty-one years of age, and was to "come free" at twenty-five, but he had too much good sense to rely upon the promises of slave-holders in matters of this kind.
column3: Thomas was of pure blood, with a very cheerful, healthy looking countenance,--twenty one years of age, and was to "come free" at twenty five, but he had too much good sense to rely upon the promises of slave holders in matters of this kind.

column2: He too belonged to Cain who, he said, was constantly talking about selling, etc.
column3: He too belonged to Cain who, he said, was constantly talking about selling, etc

column2: He left his father and mother.
column3: He left his father and mother.

column2: After being furnished with food, clothing, and free tickets, they were forwarded on in triumph and full of hope.
column3: After being furnished with food, clothing, and free tickets, they were forwarded on in triumph and full of hope.

column2: SUNDRY ARRIVALS, 1859.
column3: SUNDRY ARRIVALS, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: JOHN EDWARD LEE, JOHN HILLIS, CHARLES ROSS, JAMES RYAN, WILLIAM JOHNSTON, EDWARD WOOD, CORNELIUS FULLER AND HIS WIFE HARRIET, JOHN PINKET, ANSAL CANNON, AND JAMES BROWN.
column3: john EDWARD LEE, john HILLIS, CHARLES ROSS, james RYAN, WILLIAM JOHNSTON, EDWARD WOOD, CORNELIUS FULLER AND HIS WIFE HARRIET, john PINKET, ANSAL CANNON, AND james BROWN.

column2: John came from Maryland, and brought with him a good degree of pluck.
column3: john came from Maryland, and brought with him a good degree of pluck.

column2: He satisfied the Committee that he fully believed in freedom, and had proved his faith by his works, as he came in contact with pursuers, whom he put to flight by the use of an ugly-looking knife, which he plunged into one of them, producing quite a panic; the result was that he was left to pursue his Underground Rail Road journey without further molestation.
column3: He satisfied the Committee that he fully believed in freedom, and had proved his faith by his works, as he came in contact with pursuers, whom he put to flight by the use of an ugly looking knife, which he plunged into one of them, producing quite a panic; the result was that he was left to pursue his Underground Rail Road journey without further molestation.

column2: There was nothing in John's appearance which would lead one to suppose that he was a blood-thirsty or bad man, although a man of uncommon muscular powers; six feet high, and quite black, with resolution stamped on his countenance.
column3: There was nothing in John's appearance which would lead one to suppose that he was a blood thirsty or bad man, although a man of uncommon muscular powers; six feet high, and quite black, with resolution stamped on his countenance.

column2: But when he explained how he was enslaved by a man named John B. Slade, of Harford Co., and how, in some way or other, he became entitled to his freedom, and just as the time arrived for the consummation of his long prayed-for boon, said Slade was about to sell him,--after this provocation, it was clear enough to perceive how John came to use his knife.
column3: But when he explained how he was enslaved by a man named john b Slade, of Harford Co., and how, in some way or other, he became entitled to his freedom, and just as the time arrived for the consummation of his long prayed for boon, said Slade was about to sell him,--after this provocation, it was clear enough to perceive how john came to use his knife.

column2: John Hillis was a tiller of the ground under a widow lady (Mrs. Louisa Le Count), of the New Market District, Maryland.
column3: john Hillis was a tiller of the ground under a widow lady (mrs Louisa Le Count), of the New Market District, Maryland.

column2: He signified to the mistress, that he loved to follow the water, and that he would be just as safe on water as on land, and that he was discontented.
column3: He signified to the mistress, that he loved to follow the water, and that he would be just as safe on water as on land, and that he was discontented.

column2: The widow heard John's plausible story, and saw nothing amiss in it, so she consented that he should work on a schooner.
column3: The widow heard John's plausible story, and saw nothing amiss in it, so she consented that he should work on a schooner.

column2: The name of the craft was "Majestic." The hopeful John endeavored to do his utmost to please, and was doubly happy when he learned that the "Majestic" was to make a trip to Philadelphia.
column3: The name of the craft was "Majestic." The hopeful john endeavored to do his utmost to please, and was doubly happy when he learned that the "Majestic" was to make a trip to Philadelphia.

column2: On arriving John's eyes were opened to see that he owed Mrs. Le Count nothing, but that she was largely indebted to him for years of unrequited toil; he could not, therefore, consent to go back to her.
column3: On arriving John's eyes were opened to see that he owed mrs Le Count nothing, but that she was largely indebted to him for years of unrequited toil; he could not, therefore, consent to go back to her.

column2: He was troubled to think of his poor wife and children, whom he had left in the hands of Mrs. Harriet Dean, three quarters of a mile from New Market; but it was easier for him to imagine plans by which he could get them off than to incur the hazard of going back to Maryland; therefore he remained in freedom.
column3: He was troubled to think of his poor wife and children, whom he had left in the hands of mrs Harriet Dean, three quarters of a mile from New Market; but it was easier for him to imagine plans by which he could get them off than to incur the hazard of going back to Maryland; therefore he remained in freedom.

column2: Charles Ross was clearly of the opinion that he was free-born, but that he had been illegally held in Slavery, as were all his brothers and sisters, by a man named Rodgers, a farmer, living near Greensborough, in Caroline county, Md.
column3: Charles Ross was clearly of the opinion that he was free born, but that he had been illegally held in Slavery, as were all his brothers and sisters, by a man named Rodgers, a farmer, living near Greensborough, in Caroline county, m d.

column2: Very good reasons were given by Charles for the charge which he made against Rodgers, and it went far towards establishing the fact, that "colored men had no rights which white men were bound to respect," in Maryland.
column3: Very good reasons were given by Charles for the charge which he made against Rodgers, and it went far towards establishing the fact, that "colored men had no rights which white men were bound to respect," in Maryland.

column2: Although he was only twenty-three years of age, he had fully weighed the matter of his freedom, and appeared firmly set against Slavery.
column3: Although he was only twenty three years of age, he had fully weighed the matter of his freedom, and appeared firmly set against Slavery.

column2: William Johnson was owned by a man named John Bosley, a farmer, living near Gun Powder Neck, Maryland.
column3: William Johnson was owned by a man named john Bosley, a farmer, living near Gun Powder Neck, Maryland.

column2: One morning he, unexpectedly to William, gave him a terrible cowhiding, which, contrary to the master's designs, made him a firm believer in the doctrine of immediate abolition, and he thought, that from that hour he must do something against the system--if nothing more than to go to Canada.
column3: One morning he, unexpectedly to William, gave him a terrible cowhiding, which, contrary to the master's designs, made him a firm believer in the doctrine of immediate abolition, and he thought, that from that hour he must do something against the system-if nothing more than to go to Canada.

column2: This determination was so strong, that in a few weeks afterwards he found himself on the Underground Rail Road.
column3: This determination was so strong, that in a few weeks afterwards he found himself on the Underground Rail Road.

column2: He left one brother and one sister; his mother was dead, and of his father's whereabouts he knew nothing.
column3: He left one brother and one sister; his mother was dead, and of his father's whereabouts he knew nothing.

column2: William was nineteen years of age, brown color, smart and good-looking.
column3: William was nineteen years of age, brown color, smart and good looking.

column2: Edward Wood was a "chattel" from Drummerstown, Accomac county, Virginia, where he had been owned by a farmer, calling himself James White; a man who "drank hard and was very crabbed," and before Edward left owned eleven head of slaves.
column3: Edward Wood was a "chattel" from Drummerstown, Accomac county virginia, where he had been owned by a farmer, calling himself james White; a man who "drank hard and was very crabbed," and before Edward left owned eleven head of slaves.

column2: Edward left a wife and three children, but the strong desire to be free, which had been a ruling passion of his being from early boyhood, rendered it impossible for him to stay, although the ties were very hard to break.
column3: Edward left a wife and three children, but the strong desire to be free, which had been a ruling passion of his being from early boyhood, rendered it impossible for him to stay, although the ties were very hard to break.

column2: Slavery was crushing him hourly, and he felt that he could not submit any longer.
column3: Slavery was crushing him hourly, and he felt that he could not submit any longer.

column2: Cornelius Fuller, and his wife, Harriet, escaped together from Kent county, Maryland.
column3: Cornelius Fuller, and his wife, Harriet, escaped together from Kent county, Maryland.

column2: They belonged to separate masters; Cornelius, it was said, belonged to the Diden Estate; his wife to Judge Chambers, whose Honor lived in Chestertown.
column3: They belonged to separate masters; Cornelius, it was said, belonged to the Diden Estate; his wife to Judge Chambers, whose Honor lived in Chestertown.

column2: He is no man for freedom, bless you, said Harriet.
column3: He is no man for freedom, bless you, said Harriet.

column2: He owned more slaves than any other man in that part of the country; he sells sometimes, and he hired out a great many; would hire them to any kind of a master, if he half killed you. Cornelius and Harriet were obliged to leave their daughter Kitty, who was thirteen years of age.
column3: He owned more slaves than any other man in that part of the country; he sells sometimes, and he hired out a great many; would hire them to any kind of a master, if he half killed you. Cornelius and Harriet were obliged to leave their daughter Kitty, who was thirteen years of age.

column2: John Pinket and Ansal Cannon took the Underground Rail Road cars at New Market, Dorchester county, Maryland.
column3: john Pinket and Ansal Cannon took the Underground Rail Road cars at New Market, Dorchester county, Maryland.

column2: John was a tall young man, of twenty-seven years of age, of an active turn of mind and of a fine black color.
column3: john was a tall young man, of twenty seven years of age, of an active turn of mind and of a fine black color.

column2: He was the property of Mary Brown, a widow, firmly grounded in the love of Slavery; believing that a slave had no business to get tired or desire his freedom.
column3: He was the property of Mary Brown, a widow, firmly grounded in the love of Slavery; believing that a slave had no business to get tired or desire his freedom.

column2: She sold one of John's sisters to Georgia, and before John fled, had still in her possession nine head of slaves.
column3: She sold one of John's sisters to Georgia, and before john fled, had still in her possession nine head of slaves.

column2: She was a member of the Methodist church at East New Market.
column3: She was a member of the Methodist church at East New Market.

column2: From certain movements which looked very suspicious in John's eyes, he had been allotted to the Southern Market, he therefore resolved to look out for a habitation in Canada.
column3: From certain movements which looked very suspicious in John's eyes, he had been allotted to the Southern Market, he therefore resolved to look out for a habitation in Canada.

column2: He had a first-rate corn-field education, but no book learning.
column3: He had a first rate corn field education, but no book learning.

column2: Up to the time of his escape, John had shunned entangling himself with a wife.
column3: Up to the time of his escape, john had shunned entangling himself with a wife.

column2: Ansal was twenty-five years of age, well-colored, and seemed like a good-natured and well-behaved article.
column3: Ansal was twenty five years of age, well colored, and seemed like a good-natured and well behaved article.

column2: He escaped from Kitty Cannon, another widow, who owned nine chattels.
column3: He escaped from Kitty Cannon, another widow, who owned nine chattels.

column2: Sometimes she treated her slaves pretty well, was the testimony of Ansal.
column3: Sometimes she treated her slaves pretty well, was the testimony of Ansal.

column2: He ran away because he did not get pay for his services.
column3: He ran away because he did not get pay for his services.

column2: In thus being deprived of his hire, he concluded that he had no business to stay if he could get away.
column3: In thus being deprived of his hire, he concluded that he had no business to stay if he could get away.

column2: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND, 1859.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: JAMES BROWN.
column3: james BROWN.

column2: A more giant-like looking passenger than the above named individual had rarely ever passed over the road.
column3: A more giant like looking passenger than the above named individual had rarely ever passed over the road.

column2: He was six feet three inches high, and in every respect, a man of bone, sinew and muscle.
column3: He was six feet three inches high, and in every respect, a man of bone, sinew and muscle.

column2: For one who had enjoyed only a field hand's privileges for improvement, he was not to be despised.
column3: For one who had enjoyed only a field hand's privileges for improvement, he was not to be despised.

column2: Jim owed service to Henry Jones; at least he admitted that said Jones claimed him, and had hired him out to himself for seven dollars per month.
column3: Jim owed service to Henry Jones; at least he admitted that said Jones claimed him, and had hired him out to himself for seven dollars per month.

column2: While this amount seemed light, it was much heavier than Jim felt willing to meet solely for his master's benefit.
column3: While this amount seemed light, it was much heavier than Jim felt willing to meet solely for his master's benefit.

column2: After giving some heed to the voice of freedom within, he considered that it behooved him to try and make his way to some place where men were not guilty of wronging their neighbors out of their just hire.
column3: After giving some heed to the voice of freedom within, he considered that it behooved him to try and make his way to some place where men were not guilty of wronging their neighbors out of their just hire.

column2: Having heard of the Underground Rail Road running to Canada, he concluded to take a trip and see the country, for himself; so he arranged his affairs with this end in view, and left Henry Jones with one less to work for him for nothing.
column3: Having heard of the Underground Rail Road running to Canada, he concluded to take a trip and see the country, for himself; so he arranged his affairs with this end in view, and left Henry Jones with one less to work for him for nothing.

column2: The place that he fled from was called North Point, Baltimore county.
column3: The place that he fled from was called North Point, Baltimore county.

column2: The number of fellow-slaves left in the hands of his old master, was fifteen.
column3: The number of fellow slaves left in the hands of his old master, was fifteen.

column2: ARRIVAL FROM DELAWARE, 1859.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM DELAWARE, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: EDWARD, JOHN, AND CHARLES HALL.
column3: EDWARD, john, AND CHARLES HALL.

column2: The above named individuals were brothers from Delaware.
column3: The above named individuals were brothers from Delaware.

column2: They were young; the eldest being about twenty, the youngest not far from seventeen years of age.
column3: They were young; the eldest being about twenty, the youngest not far from seventeen years of age.

column2: Edward was serving on a farm, under a man named Booth.
column3: Edward was serving on a farm, under a man named Booth.

column2: Perceiving that Booth was "running through his property" very fast by hard drinking, Edward's better judgment admonished him that his so-called master would one day have need of more rum money, and that he might not be too good to offer him in the market for what he would bring.
column3: Perceiving that Booth was "running through his property" very fast by hard drinking, Edward's better judgment admonished him that his so-called master would one day have need of more rum money, and that he might not be too good to offer him in the market for what he would bring.

column2: Charles resolved that when his brothers crossed the line dividing Delaware and Pennsylvania, he would not be far behind.
column3: Charles resolved that when his brothers crossed the line dividing Delaware and Pennsylvania, he would not be far behind.

column2: The mother of these boys was freed at the age of twenty-eight, and lived in Wilmington, Delaware.
column3: The mother of these boys was freed at the age of twenty eight, and lived in wilmington delaware.

column2: It was owing to the fact that their mother had been freed that they entertained the vague notion that they too might be freed; but it was a well established fact that thousands lived and died in such a hope without ever realizing their expectations.
column3: It was owing to the fact that their mother had been freed that they entertained the vague notion that they too might be freed; but it was a well established fact that thousands lived and died in such a hope without ever realizing their expectations.

column2: The boys, more shrewd and wide awake than many others, did not hearken to such "stuff." The two younger heard the views of the elder brother, and expressed a willingness to follow him.
column3: The boys, more shrewd and wide awake than many others, did not hearken to such "stuff." The two younger heard the views of the elder brother, and expressed a willingness to follow him.

column2: Edward, becoming satisfied that what they meant to do must be done quickly, took the lead, and off they started for a free State.
column3: Edward, becoming satisfied that what they meant to do must be done quickly, took the lead, and off they started for a free State.

column2: John was owned by one James B. Rodgers, a farmer, and "a most every kind of man," as John expressed himself; in fact John thought that his owner was such a strange, wicked, and cross character that he couldn't tell himself what he was.
column3: john was owned by one james b Rodgers, a farmer, and "a most every kind of man," as john expressed himself; in fact john thought that his owner was such a strange, wicked, and cross character that he couldn't tell himself what he was.

column2: Seeing that slaves were treated no better than dogs and hogs, John thought that he was none too young to be taking steps to get away.
column3: Seeing that slaves were treated no better than dogs and hogs, john thought that he was none too young to be taking steps to get away.

column2: Charles was held by James Rodgers, Sr., under whom he said that he had served nine years with faint prospects of some time becoming free, but when, was doubtful.
column3: Charles was held by james Rodgers senior, under whom he said that he had served nine years with faint prospects of some time becoming free, but when, was doubtful.
